It was good in the way his work always was lately: smooth, controlled, shimmering with phrasing that felt both fresh and strangely generic at the same time. It began with a vivid sensory image, moved quickly into a characterâ€™s internal conflict, introduced a mystery by the end of the first page. It was like watching someone juggle expertly.

Mara read carefully, trying to catch the seams. She found none. Or perhaps she found too many, in small ways: metaphors that piled neatly, emotional beats that arrived exactly when expected. It had the shape of quality.

When they finished reading, there was that moment of silence when everyone decided how much honesty the group could tolerate.

Lyle spoke first, as usual. â€œWell,â€ he said, smiling broadly. â€œEthan, youâ€™ve done it again.â€

Ethan gave a modest shrug. â€œJust playing around,â€ he said. â€œYou know.â€

Neil chuckled. â€œPlaying around,â€ he repeated, as if the phrase itself were funny.

Juniper spoke with careful appreciation. â€œThe imagery is strong,â€ she said. â€œEspecially the â€˜streetlights like coins in a fountain.â€™â€

Harrietâ€™s hands were folded tightly in her lap. She said nothing.

Mara cleared her throat, surprising herself. â€œCan I ask something?â€ she said.

All eyes turned to her. The shift was subtle but immediate, like a spotlight snapping on.

â€œSure,â€ Lyle said, his smile still fixed. â€œGo ahead.â€

Mara felt her mouth go dry. She had not rehearsed this. She had not planned the exact words. She only knew she couldnâ€™t keep swallowing the question forever.

â€œItâ€™sâ€¦ not about the story exactly,â€ Mara said slowly. She heard the caution in her own voice, the way she tried to make herself small. â€œItâ€™s about process.â€

Ethanâ€™s smile remained, but his eyes sharpened slightly. â€œOkay,â€ he said.

Mara took a breath. â€œAre weâ€¦ using AI tools in this group?â€ she asked. â€œLike, to generate drafts or rewrite things?â€

The room went still. Mara felt the collective attention, the tension that had been lurking beneath the groupâ€™s politeness.

Lyleâ€™s smile faltered. â€œWeâ€¦ talked about that briefly,â€ he said, and his tone was light, too light. â€œLast month, remember?â€

Harrietâ€™s cheeks flushed again.

Mara nodded. â€œYes. But it didnâ€™t really get discussed,â€ she said. â€œAnd Iâ€™m not trying to accuse anyone. Iâ€™m justâ€¦ wondering if we have an expectation. Like, if people are using it, do we disclose it?â€

Neil laughed, short and dismissive. â€œWhy do you care?â€ he said, not cruelly, but with the ease of someone who assumed the group would back him.

Juniperâ€™s eyes flicked between Mara and Ethan. She looked like she wanted to speak, but didnâ€™t.

Ethan leaned forward. â€œAre you asking me?â€ he said, still smiling.

Maraâ€™s heart pounded. She could feel Harriet beside her, rigid as stone.

â€œIâ€™m asking the group,â€ Mara said. â€œBut yes, I guess Iâ€™m asking you too. Because your work hasâ€¦ changed.â€

There was a sharp intake of breath from someone across the circle. Mara couldnâ€™t tell who.

Ethanâ€™s smile tightened. â€œSo you *are* accusing,â€ he said.

â€œNo,â€ Mara said quickly. â€œIâ€™m sayingâ€”â€

â€œYouâ€™re implying Iâ€™m cheating,â€ Ethan said, his voice still calm but now edged with something hard. â€œBecause my writing improved.â€

Neil shook his head as if Mara had committed a social crime. â€œCome on,â€ he said. â€œPeople canâ€™t get better without being suspected now?â€

Mara felt the ground shifting beneath her. This was the social pressure Harriet had named: the way suspicion could be reframed as jealousy, the way raising a concern could make you the problem.

Harriet finally spoke. Her voice trembled. â€œItâ€™s not about you getting better,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s about honesty.â€

Ethanâ€™s eyes snapped to Harriet. â€œOh,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s you again.â€

Harriet flinched.

Lyle raised both hands. â€œOkay,â€ he said quickly. â€œLetâ€™s slow down. No one is accusing anyone. Weâ€™re having a conversation.â€

But his tone was pleading now, not authoritative. Mara saw it: Lyleâ€™s fear that the group was about to crack.

Neil scoffed. â€œThis is ridiculous,â€ he said. â€œIf people are using tools, so what? We all use tools. We use thesauruses. We use grammar checkers. We use critique partners. You want to ban Google next?â€

Juniper finally spoke, her voice quiet but steady. â€œItâ€™s not the same,â€ she said. â€œA thesaurus doesnâ€™t write your sentence.â€

Neil rolled his eyes. â€œYou donâ€™t know what people are doing. You donâ€™t know where the line is.â€

â€œThatâ€™s why weâ€™re talking about it,â€ Mara said.

Ethan leaned back in his chair. â€œYou want a rule?â€ he said. â€œFine. Hereâ€™s a rule: donâ€™t be a jerk.â€

Mara felt heat rise in her face. â€œThatâ€™s notâ€”â€

â€œI come here,â€ Ethan continued, â€œbecause itâ€™s supposed to be supportive. Because Iâ€™m trying to write. And now Iâ€™m being interrogated like Iâ€™m on trial. Itâ€™s gross.â€

Harrietâ€™s hands clenched. â€œNo one is interrogating you,â€ she said, but her voice sounded small in the room.

Lyle looked at Mara, then at Harriet, then at Ethan. He looked like someone trying to hold water in his hands.

â€œMaybe,â€ Lyle said cautiously, â€œmaybe we can agree that if someone is using AI in a significant way, they should mention it. Just for transparency.â€

Ethanâ€™s mouth curled. â€œSo weâ€™re doing disclosure,â€ he said, and the word sounded like something legal. â€œWhat counts as â€˜significantâ€™?â€

Neil nodded eagerly, seizing the loophole. â€œExactly,â€ he said. â€œThis is why itâ€™s stupid. You canâ€™t define it. And if you try, youâ€™ll just make people feel policed.â€

Harrietâ€™s shoulders sagged slightly, as if sheâ€™d been expecting this.

Mara felt despair wash through her. The conversation was turning into a trap: if you pushed for clarity, you looked controlling; if you accepted vagueness, nothing changed.

Juniper said softly, â€œMaybe people could just be honest without it being a rule.â€

Neil snorted. â€œPeople are honest,â€ he said. â€œYouâ€™re acting like weâ€™re all liars.â€

Ethan looked at Mara. His expression had softened into something like pity. â€œYou know what this is?â€ he said. â€œThis is insecurity. Youâ€™re uncomfortable because your writing feels messy and mine doesnâ€™t. So you want to believe I didnâ€™t earn it.â€

Maraâ€™s throat tightened. The accusation stung because it contained a sliver of truth: Mara *was* insecure. Writing made her insecure by default. But insecurity didnâ€™t mean she was wrong.

â€œIâ€™m uncomfortable because I donâ€™t know what weâ€™re critiquing,â€ Mara said, her voice shaking now despite her efforts. â€œBecause if someone uses AI to generate prose, and we workshop it as if itâ€™s their craft, that changes what this group is.â€

Ethan shrugged. â€œItâ€™s still writing,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s still a story. It still needs taste. It still needs editing. You think you can just press a button and get something good? Thatâ€™s not how it works.â€

Mara stared at him. He sounded rehearsed. He sounded like someone whoâ€™d had this argument online and learned the talking points.

Harriet whispered, â€œThatâ€™s exactly what people say.â€

Ethanâ€™s eyes flashed. â€œExcuse me?â€

Harriet swallowed. â€œNothing,â€ she said quickly.

Mara felt the moment slipping. She felt the groupâ€™s discomfort rising like steam, and with it the urge to seal the conversation shut. Harmony was a powerful narcotic.

Lyle cleared his throat. â€œOkay,â€ he said, his voice strained. â€œI thinkâ€¦ I think weâ€™ve aired some feelings. Maybe we can revisit this later. For now, letâ€™s get back to the workshop. Juniper, youâ€™re up.â€

The group moved on because Lyle asked them to, because moving on was easier than staying. Pages were passed around. Juniperâ€™s poem was read. People commented gently. The circle returned to its usual shape, but Mara felt the crack running through it.

As the meeting ended, people avoided Maraâ€™s eyes. Not all of them, but enough that she felt the social correction: *You made this uncomfortable. You broke the spell.*

Ethan packed his bag quickly. As he stood, he leaned toward Mara, his voice low.

â€œJust so you know,â€ he said, â€œI donâ€™t use AI.â€

Mara looked up at him. His face was open, almost earnest.

â€œI work my ass off,â€ Ethan continued. â€œI write every day. I revise. I read craft books. And the fact that youâ€™d assume otherwiseâ€¦ that says more about you than me.â€

Maraâ€™s mouth opened, but no words came out. She didnâ€™t know how to respond to a statement that could be true and still not resolve anything.

Ethan straightened. â€œGood night,â€ he said, and walked out.

Harriet lingered, stuffing her notebook into her bag with trembling hands. Mara waited until most people had left before approaching her.

Harriet looked up. Her eyes were wet, but she blinked quickly, refusing the tears.

â€œI shouldnâ€™t have spoken,â€ Harriet whispered.

Maraâ€™s chest tightened. â€œYes, you should have,â€ she said.

Harriet shook her head. â€œLook what happened,â€ she said. â€œNow Iâ€™mâ€¦ the crazy one.â€

Mara glanced around. Lyle was stacking chairs again, his shoulders tense. Juniper hovered near the door as if wanting to come back but not knowing how. Neil was already gone.

â€œWeâ€™re not crazy,â€ Mara said, though she didnâ€™t entirely believe it. â€œWe justâ€¦ touched the wrong nerve.â€

Harriet let out a shaky laugh that sounded like a sob. â€œHe said he doesnâ€™t use it,â€ she said.

Mara nodded slowly. â€œHe told me the same,â€ she said. â€œButâ€¦ even if he doesnâ€™t, the question still matters.â€

Harriet stared at her. â€œDoes it?â€ she asked. â€œOr did we just ruin everything for nothing?â€

Mara didnâ€™t know. She only knew the room felt colder now, less like a circle and more like a stage.

---

For the next few weeks, the group changed in small ways that Mara couldnâ€™t stop noticing.

People were kinder to Ethan. They praised him more effusively, as if compensating. They laughed at his jokes. They asked him about his process in admiring tones. It was the groupâ€™s way of soothing the wound Mara and Harriet had made.

People were colder to Harriet. Not overtly, not cruelly. Justâ€¦ less. They gave her polite feedback. They didnâ€™t linger to chat with her. They didnâ€™t ask about her work outside the group. They avoided being seen as aligned with her.

Mara felt herself being tested too. Would she apologize? Would she smooth things over? Would she prove she wasnâ€™t a threat to the groupâ€™s comfort?

She found herself doing small things to reassure people. She complimented Neilâ€™s jokes. She thanked Lyle more than usual. She laughed at Ethanâ€™s comments even when they werenâ€™t funny. She hated herself for it, but she also wanted to belong.

Harriet stopped coming to the cafÃ© meetups. She still attended the library meetings, but she sat quieter than before, shrinking into herself.

Juniper, once, caught Mara outside after a meeting. She had her scarf wrapped around her neck and her hands tucked into her sleeves.

â€œI think you were right to ask,â€ Juniper said softly.

Mara felt a wave of relief. â€œThank you,â€ she said.

Juniper looked down at the pavement. â€œBut I also thinkâ€¦ the group canâ€™t handle it,â€ she said.

Maraâ€™s relief turned to a bitter amusement. â€œSo what do we do?â€ she asked.

Juniper shrugged. â€œWe write,â€ she said. â€œAnd we try not to break each other.â€

Mara watched Juniper walk away, feeling that familiar loneliness again. Writing was lonely. Community was supposed to make it less so. But community, she was learning, came with its own loneliness: the loneliness of knowing what you couldnâ€™t say.

One evening, Mara found herself scrolling online after dinner, reading thread after thread about AI writing. People argued viciously. People posted screenshots of â€œAI detectorsâ€ and called each other frauds. People insisted that using AI was no different than using a calculator. People insisted it was the death of art.

Mara closed her laptop, her eyes aching, and stared at the blank wall of her living room.

She thought about Ethanâ€™s story. She thought about her own messy draft on her desk, the one she hadnâ€™t submitted because she didnâ€™t trust it yet.

She thought about what Harriet had said: comparing yourself to something that isnâ€™t real.

Was that what was happening? Was the group becoming a place where reality was negotiable? Where the image of being a writer mattered more than the difficult, awkward process of writing?

Mara didnâ€™t know. But she knew she couldnâ€™t unsee the social pressure now. The way people downplayed suspicion to preserve comfort. The way they punished those who named it.

The next month, Mara showed up with a new story. It was rougher than she liked. It had a paragraph that didnâ€™t work. It had dialogue that needed tightening. But it was hers, and she decided to bring it anyway as a kind of stubborn act.

When she passed it around, Ethan smiled at her. â€œLooking forward to it,â€ he said.

Mara nodded, trying to read his expression. She couldnâ€™t tell if he was sincere or performing.

As the group read, Mara watched Harriet. Harriet held Maraâ€™s pages carefully, as if handling something fragile. Harrietâ€™s eyes moved slowly, taking time. When she finished, she looked up and met Maraâ€™s gaze. For a second, there was a small, fierce understanding between them.

When the critique began, Lyle smiled and said something supportive. Neil made a joke. Ethan offered polished advice. Mara took notes. She thanked them.

The meeting ended. People stood, gathered their things, joked about the weather. The fluorescent lights hummed.

Mara lingered, watching the group reassemble itself into normalcy. She realized that the groupâ€™s downplaying wasnâ€™t just avoidance. It was a form of control. It kept the group functioning, yes, but it also kept everyone in line. If you raised the wrong question, you would be reminded, gently or not, that comfort mattered more.

Harriet approached Mara and handed her pages back. Her fingers brushed Maraâ€™s, and Harriet said quietly, â€œI liked the messy parts.â€

Mara blinked. â€œYou did?â€ she asked.

Harriet nodded. â€œThey felt alive,â€ she said. Then she hesitated, glanced toward the door where Ethan and Neil were laughing, and added, â€œAlive is rare.â€

Mara felt a lump rise in her throat. She wanted to hug Harriet, but she didnâ€™t. Hugging was not something the group did. Physical affection would be another breach of the unspoken rules.

Instead, Mara said softly, â€œDo you want to start something else?â€

Harriet frowned. â€œWhat do you mean?â€

â€œA smaller group,â€ Mara said. â€œJust a few of us. People who want to talk honestly about process. Whoâ€¦ donâ€™t mind discomfort.â€

Harrietâ€™s eyes widened. â€œThat would beâ€¦ splitting the group,â€ she whispered.

Mara nodded. â€œMaybe,â€ she said. â€œOr maybe itâ€™s justâ€¦ making a space where we can breathe.â€

Harriet looked torn. She glanced toward Lyle, toward Juniper, toward the empty chairs. â€œLyle would be hurt,â€ she said.

â€œI know,â€ Mara replied. â€œBut Lyle is already hurt,â€ she added, though she didnâ€™t say it aloud. Hurt by the tension he couldnâ€™t manage. Hurt by the reality he refused to name.

Harriet looked back at Mara. â€œWho would come?â€ she asked.

Mara thought of Juniperâ€™s quiet courage. She thought of one or two others who had looked uncomfortable during the AI conversation but had stayed silent. She thought of the possibility of something smaller and truer.

â€œJuniper,â€ Mara said. â€œMaybe Tanya. Maybeâ€¦ even Lyle, if he wanted to.â€

Harriet gave a small, uncertain laugh. â€œLyle likes rules,â€ she said.

â€œSo do I,â€ Mara said. â€œBut I like the right rules.â€

Harriet looked at Mara for a long moment. Then she nodded once, decisively, as if she were stepping over a line.

â€œOkay,â€ Harriet said. â€œLetâ€™s do it.â€

Mara felt something loosen inside her chest. Not a solution, not peace, but a small permission: permission to stop pretending.

They exchanged details quickly, quiet as conspirators. A different library room. A different night. A smaller circle.

As they walked out together, Mara noticed that Juniper was still by the door, lingering as if unsure where to go. Juniper saw Mara and Harriet, and something in her expression shifted. She stepped closer.

â€œYouâ€™re leaving?â€ Juniper asked, her voice careful.

Mara hesitated. She felt the familiar pressure: donâ€™t make this awkward, donâ€™t fracture the group, donâ€™t become the villain.

But she also felt Harriet beside her, steady now.

â€œWeâ€™reâ€¦ starting something smaller,â€ Mara said honestly. â€œA process-focused thing.â€

Juniperâ€™s eyes searched Maraâ€™s face. â€œBecause ofâ€¦?â€ she began.

Mara didnâ€™t want to say â€œAIâ€ in the library hallway where other patrons could hear. But Juniper seemed to understand anyway.

Juniper looked down, then back up. â€œCan I come?â€ she asked, and there was a quiet urgency in her voice.

Mara felt a rush of warmth. â€œYes,â€ she said. â€œPlease.â€

Juniper exhaled as if sheâ€™d been holding her breath for weeks. â€œOkay,â€ she whispered. â€œOkay.â€

They walked out into the cold together, three figures stepping away from the bright, humming room where politeness had been the price of belonging.

In the parking lot, Lyle waved at them from across the way, cheerful, unaware. Ethanâ€™s laughter echoed as he climbed into his car.

Mara raised her hand and waved back, because she wasnâ€™t trying to punish anyone. She wasnâ€™t trying to win. She was simply trying to find a place where the work could be what it was: messy, difficult, human.

As she drove home, Mara thought about the group they were leaving behind. She thought about how people would talk. She imagined the narrative forming: Mara and Harriet couldnâ€™t handle it. Mara was jealous. Harriet was paranoid. Juniper was sensitive. The story would be tidy, because tidy stories were comforting.

But Mara also thought about her own drafts, the ones with rough edges and awkward lines and moments that didnâ€™t quite land. She thought about the way those drafts felt like her, in a way no polished paragraph ever could.

At a red light, Mara glanced at her passenger seat, where her folder lay slightly open, pages peeking out like something restless. She imagined a future where writing groups had to decide what they were: places for products, or places for people. Places for performance, or places for process.

She didnâ€™t know which future would win. She didnâ€™t know what Ethan truly did or didnâ€™t do. She didnâ€™t know how many people in the world were quietly outsourcing their sentences and still calling it their voice.

What she did know was this: suspicion thrived in silence, and silence was not the same thing as kindness.

The light turned green. Mara drove on, carrying her messy pages into the night, toward a smaller circle where discomfort might be allowed to exist, and where the pressure to downplay might finally lift, at least for a few hours at a time.

And somewhere beneath all the fear and awkwardness and fragile alliances, Mara felt something that had been missing in the fluorescent room: a flicker of honest anticipation.

Not for applause. Not for perfection.

For the work itself.

# The Wednesday Circle

The coffee shop had been their sanctuary for three years now. Every Wednesday at seven, the back room of CaffÃ¨ Letterario filled with the quiet shuffling of manuscripts, the click of laptop keys, and the particular nervous energy that accompanies people about to share something vulnerable. Margaret Chen had founded the group when she'd moved to the city after her divorce, seeking community among strangers who understood the peculiar loneliness of putting words on a page.

Tonight, she arrived early as always, arranging the mismatched chairs into their familiar circle. Seven chairs. They'd started with twelve members, but attrition had whittled them down to a committed core: herself, Douglas, Priya, Nathan, Elise, Omar, andâ€”as of four months agoâ€”Carolyn.

Carolyn. Margaret smoothed the printout of tonight's submission against the wooden table, feeling the weight of what she was about to do.

"You're here early." Douglas appeared in the doorway, his gray beard neat as always, his leather satchel bulging with manuscripts he'd marked up in his careful hand. He taught English at the community college and brought a teacher's thoroughness to his critiques.

"Couldn't sleep," Margaret said. "You know how it is before workshop nights."

Douglas settled into his usual chair with a grunt. "Whose work is up tonight? I've lost track."

"Carolyn's. The new chapter of her novel."

Something flickered across Douglas's faceâ€”a tightening around the eyes that Margaret recognized because she'd felt it herself. "Ah," he said. "Yes. I read it."

The silence between them stretched like taffy. Margaret wanted to say something, to crack open the conversation that had been calcifying in her chest for weeks. But before she could find the words, Priya swept in with her usual energy, bangles jangling, a canvas bag overflowing with notebooks.

"Traffic was a nightmare," she announced, unwinding a silk scarf from her neck. "I swear this city gets worse everyâ€”oh, we're early. Just us?"

"The others will be here soon," Margaret said.

Priya dropped into a chair, already pulling out her marked-up copy of Carolyn's chapter. Margaret noticed she'd used fewer sticky notes than usual. Priya, who normally covered every page in a riot of color-coded annotations, had used perhaps four or five.

"So," Priya said, and her voice had that carefully neutral quality that meant she was working hard to keep something out of it. "What did everyone think?"

Again, that silence. Douglas studied his hands. Margaret felt the weight of the printout in her lap.

"It's very polished," Douglas finally said.

"Yes," Priya agreed. "Very polished. Very..."

"Clean," Margaret offered.

"Clean," Priya repeated. "That's the word."

Nathan arrived next, shaking rain from his jacket, followed by Elise and Omar, who'd apparently shared an Uber from the university district. By seven o'clock, they were arranged in their circle, coffee cups steaming, Carolyn's chapter distributed before them like evidence at a trial.

Carolyn herself rushed in at 7:05, apologizing breathlessly. She was younger than the rest of themâ€”late twenties to their forties and fiftiesâ€”with the bright-eyed enthusiasm of someone who still believed publication was just around the corner. When she'd joined the group four months ago, she'd been working on what she called a "multigenerational saga about immigration and identity." Her first submission had been rough but promising, full of jagged edges and raw emotion.

Now Margaret looked at the chapter in her lap, at its seamless transitions and perfectly calibrated emotional beats, and felt something cold settle in her stomach.

"Sorry, sorry," Carolyn said, sliding into the last empty chair. "Work ran late. Did I miss anything?"

"We were just about to start," Margaret said. "You know the drill. We'll go around the circle with our feedback, and you stay quiet until we're done. Then you can ask questions."

Carolyn nodded, her pen poised over a fresh notebook. She looked eager. Hopeful. Margaret remembered that feeling from her own early days in workshops, that desperate hunger for validation mixed with terror of criticism.

"I'll start," Douglas said, clearing his throat. He always went firstâ€”a professorial habit. "This chapter represents a significant step forward for the manuscript. The prose isâ€”" He paused, seeming to search for words. "â€”accomplished. The scene where Mei-Lin confronts her grandmother about the family secrets is particularly effective. The dialogue feels natural, and the emotional stakes are clear."

He stopped. In three years of workshops, Margaret had never heard Douglas give such brief feedback. He usually spoke for ten minutes minimum, citing craft books and literary precedents, drawing connections to the writer's earlier work.

"That's... that's all I have," he said. "Good work."

Carolyn beamed. "Thank you, Douglas. That means so much."

The circle turned to Priya, who was studying her copy with unusual intensity. "I agree with Douglas," she said. "The craft here is really strong. The way you wove the historical flashbacks with the present-day narrativeâ€”very smooth. Very seamless." She emphasized the last word slightly, and Margaret saw Omar shift in his seat.

"I did have one small note," Priya continued. "The grandmother's voice in this chapter feels different from how she spoke in chapter three. More... formal? I wondered if that was intentional."

"Oh, definitely intentional," Carolyn said quickly, then caught herself. "Sorry, I know I'm supposed to stay quiet."

"It's fine," Margaret said. "We can discuss after."

Nathan went next. He was the quietest member of the group, a software engineer who wrote spare, Carver-esque short stories about loneliness in the digital age. His feedback was always thoughtful, always precise.

"The writing is technically proficient," he said, and something in his tone made Margaret's breath catch. "Very technically proficient. I noticed the sentence structures are more varied than in your earlier chapters. Lots of complex-compound constructions that weren't there before. The vocabulary is also more sophisticated. Words like 'ephemeral' and 'juxtaposition' that I don't remember seeing in your previous work."

The room went very still.

"I'm not saying that's bad," Nathan added quickly. "Writers grow. That's what workshops are for. I'm just noting the change."

Carolyn's smile had faltered slightly. "I've been reading a lot more literary fiction lately. Trying to level up my prose, you know?"

Nathan nodded, but he didn't look at her.

Elise jumped in with more generous feedback, praising the chapter's emotional resonance and cultural specificity. Omar focused on structural elements, suggesting the flashback in the middle might work better at the end. Both of them talked more than usual, as if trying to fill a silence that kept threatening to swallow the room.

Then it was Margaret's turn.

She'd been dreading this moment for three weeks, ever since she'd opened Carolyn's submission and felt her stomach drop. She'd read it once, then again, then a third time with a growing sense of unease she couldn't quite name. That night, she'd lain awake staring at the ceiling, trying to identify what was wrong.

The writing was good. That was the problem. It was too goodâ€”not in the way that great literature is good, but in a different way. A smoothness that felt manufactured. An absence of the particular quirks and consistent imperfections that marked a human voice.

Margaret had spent thirty years as an editor before retirement. She'd shaped thousands of manuscripts, learned to recognize each writer's fingerprints in their prose. She knew what it looked like when a writer struggled, grew, broke through. She knew the awkward beauty of authentic development.

This wasn't that.

But what could she say? She had no proof. Just a feeling, a editor's instinct honed over decades, and the knowledge that voicing her suspicions would shatter something fragile in this room.

"Margaret?" Priya prompted.

"Sorry." Margaret looked down at her notes, which were mostly questions she couldn't bring herself to ask. "I think this chapter shows tremendous growth, Carolyn. The prose is very... controlled. Very uniform in its quality."

She let the words hang there, weighted with implication. Across the circle, Douglas caught her eye. She saw understanding there, and something like reliefâ€”the relief of not being alone in her suspicions.

"I do have some questions about your process," Margaret continued. "When you wrote this chapter, did you draft it all at once? Or in pieces?"

Carolyn tilted her head. "Um, in pieces, I think? Over a couple weeks."

"And did you revise much? The prose feels very polished for a workshop draft."

"I always revise before submitting. Isn't that what we're supposed to do?"

"Of course," Margaret said. "I just wondered about your approach. The voice here is quite different from your earlier work."

She was skating close to the edge now, closer than she wanted to go. But before she could pull back, Carolyn's expression shiftedâ€”a flash of something defensive, almost frightened.

"Different how?" Carolyn asked.

Margaret hesitated. The rest of the group was watching, their silence heavy with unspoken thoughts. She could feel them all teetering on the same precipice, wanting someone else to be the first to jump.

"Just more refined," she finally said. "That's all. It's a compliment."

The rest of the feedback session passed in a blur of careful praise and gentle suggestions. Nobody mentioned the elephant in the room. Nobody asked the question that Margaret knew they were all thinking.

---

Afterwards, at the bar across the street where they always went to decompress, the real conversation began.

Carolyn had begged off, citing an early meeting. The moment she was gone, something released in the groupâ€”a collective exhale of held breath.

"Okay," Priya said, setting down her wine glass. "Are we going to talk about this?"

"Talk about what?" Omar asked, though his tone suggested he knew exactly what.

"You know what. That chapter. That... whatever that was."

"It was good writing," Elise said, but her voice was uncertain.

"Was it, though?" Nathan leaned forward, his usual reticence abandoned. "Was it good writing, or was it just... competent? Polished? Like something generated byâ€”"

"Don't," Douglas interrupted. "Don't say it."

"Why not?" Nathan asked. "We're all thinking it."

"Because we don't know," Douglas said. "We suspect, maybe. But we don't know. And accusing someone of using AI to write their work isâ€”it's a serious accusation. It's basically calling them a fraud."

"Is it, though?" Priya asked. "I mean, lots of people use AI for editing now. For brainstorming. Where's the line?"

"The line is passing off AI-generated text as your own work," Nathan said. "That's the line."

Margaret had been silent, nursing her bourbon, but now she spoke. "The question is, what do we do about it? Assuming our suspicions are correctâ€”and I want to be clear, we don't know that they areâ€”what are our options?"

The group exchanged uncomfortable glances.

"We could just... not say anything," Elise offered. "Let it go. Maybe we're wrong."

"And if we're not wrong?" Nathan asked. "Then we're sitting in workshop every week, pretending to critique work that a computer wrote. What's the point of that? Why are we even here?"

"We're here to support each other," Omar said quietly. "That's what writing groups do."

"Support each other in what? In pretending? In performing authenticity while the whole thing is a lie?"

"You don't know it's a lie," Douglas said again. "That's my point. You're making assumptions based onâ€”what? A feeling? The fact that her writing got better?"

"It didn't get better," Margaret said. All eyes turned to her. "It got different. There's a distinction. When a writer improves, you can see the trajectory. You can see them struggling with the same problems in new ways, building on their strengths, developing their weaknesses into something personal. What happened with Carolyn's work isn't improvement. It's replacement."

"Replacement," Priya repeated. "That's a good word for it."

"But we still don't have proof," Douglas insisted.

"What kind of proof would satisfy you?" Nathan asked. "A confession? A screenshot of her ChatGPT history?"

"I just think we should be careful aboutâ€”"

"About what? About protecting our cozy little community? About not rocking the boat?" Nathan's voice was rising. "I quit my writing group back in Portland because it was too comfortable, too full of people telling each other what they wanted to hear. I thought this group was different. I thought we cared about the work."

"We do care about the work," Elise said. "That's why this is so hard. Because if we're right, then the work isn't real. And if we're wrong, we've destroyed someone's reputation over nothing."

The table fell silent. Margaret swirled the last of her bourbon, watching the amber liquid catch the light.

"There's another option," she said slowly. "We don't accuse anyone of anything. But we adjust our approach. Start asking more questions about process. Ask people to bring in their drafts, their revision histories. Talk more about the journey of creation, not just the destination."

"You mean make it harder for someone to fake," Priya said.

"I mean make it about more than the final product. If writing workshops are just about polished pages, then yes, AI makes them irrelevant. But if they're about the struggle, the growth, the human experience of creationâ€”then there's still value in what we do."

"That's a nice idea," Nathan said, "but it doesn't solve the immediate problem. What do we do about Carolyn? Do we keep workshopping her AI-generated chapters like nothing's wrong?"

Margaret didn't have an answer for that. None of them did.

---

The following Wednesday, Margaret arrived at CaffÃ¨ Letterario to find Carolyn already there, sitting alone in the back room, staring at her phone.

"You're early," Margaret said, surprised.

Carolyn looked up. Her eyes were red-rimmed, her usual brightness dimmed. "Margaret. Can we talk? Before the others get here?"

Something heavy settled in Margaret's chest. "Of course."

She sat down across from Carolyn, close enough to see the slight tremor in the younger woman's hands.

"I know what you all think," Carolyn said quietly. "About my writing. About how it's changed."

Margaret said nothing. She'd learned, in her decades as an editor, that sometimes the best response was silence.

"You think I'm using AI. That I'm cheating."

"We haven't accused you of anything."

"You haven't had to." Carolyn laughed, a brittle sound. "I could feel it in workshop last week. The way everyone was looking at me. The careful way you all chose your words. Like you were handling evidence."

Margaret took a slow breath. "Are you?"

"Am I what?"

"Using AI. To write your chapters."

The question hung in the air between them, naked and uncomfortable. Carolyn's face went through several expressionsâ€”fear, anger, something that might have been shameâ€”before settling into a kind of weary resignation.

"It's not that simple," she said.

"It seems fairly simple to me."

"No, you don't understand. Iâ€”" Carolyn broke off, pressing her fingers to her temples. "When I joined this group, I was so excited. Finally, a real writing community. People who would take my work seriously, help me get better. And that first submissionâ€”you remember how rough it was. Everyone was so kind, but I could tell. I could tell it wasn't good enough."

"That's what workshops are for," Margaret said. "To help you improve."

"I know. And I tried. I really tried. But the feedback just made it worse. The more I understood what was wrong with my writing, the less I could write at all. Every sentence felt inadequate before I even finished typing it. I'd spend hours on a single paragraph and then delete everything because I knew it wasn't right. I knew I couldn't make it right."

Margaret recognized this. She'd seen it before, in writers who received criticism before they were ready for it, whose creative confidence shattered under the weight of their own newly acquired discernment. The gap between taste and ability, Ira Glass had called it. The thing that kills young artists.

"So you turned to AI," Margaret said, not a question.

Carolyn nodded miserably. "At first, it was just brainstorming. I'd talk to it about my plot, my characters. It was like having a collaborator who was always available, never judged me. Then I started asking it to help with specific passages. Just to see how it would handle scenes I was stuck on. And the things it produced wereâ€”they were good, Margaret. Better than anything I could write."

"So you started submitting its work as your own."

"Not exactly. I'd take what it wrote and revise it. Change things. Put my own spin on it." She looked up, something pleading in her eyes. "Doesn't that count? If I'm shaping it, directing it, making choices about what stays and what goes?"

"Is that what you did with this last chapter?"

Carolyn was silent.

"I didn't think so," Margaret said.

"You don't understand what it's like," Carolyn said, her voice rising. "You've been writing for decades. You have a voice, a style, skills you developed over years of practice. I'm starting from nothing. I'm supposed to compete with people who've been doing this their whole lives? Who have natural talent I'll never have?"

"Writing isn't a competition."

"Everything is a competition. Every publishing slot that goes to someone else is a slot that doesn't go to me. Every reader who picks up someone else's book is a reader I've lost. The market is saturated, agents want perfection from the first page, and I'm supposed to just... keep producing rough drafts? Keep being bad in public while I slowly, maybe, possibly, get better? If I ever get better?"

Margaret felt the old familiar ache of compassion and frustration that characterized her relationship with struggling writers. She understood Carolyn's desperation. She also knew it was corroding something essential.

"Let me tell you something," Margaret said. "In my thirty years as an editor, I worked with hundreds of writers. Some of them were brilliant from the first page. Natural talents who made it look easy. But most of them weren't. Most of them were mediocre when they started. They wrote terrible first drafts and slowly, painfully, learned to make them better. They spent years in the wilderness of inadequacy. And many of themâ€”the ones who persistedâ€”eventually produced work that mattered."

"And the ones who didn't persist?"

"They found other ways to express themselves. Or they made peace with writing as a hobby rather than a career. Or they moved on entirely. There's no shame in any of those paths."

"But I don't want those paths." Carolyn's voice cracked. "I want to be a writer. A real writer. Someone who creates something meaningful."

"Then you have to actually create it," Margaret said gently. "What you're doing nowâ€”it's not creation. It's curation. You're selecting and arranging things that someone elseâ€”something elseâ€”produced. That might feel like writing, but it isn't. And somewhere inside you, you know that. That's why you're sitting here with red eyes before workshop, dreading what's about to happen."

Carolyn looked away. When she spoke again, her voice was barely above a whisper. "What am I supposed to do?"

"That's up to you. But I think you need to decide what you actually want. Do you want to have written something? Or do you want to be someone who writes?"

Before Carolyn could answer, the door opened. Priya swept in, followed by Douglas, their voices bright with casual conversation that died when they saw the two women sitting in silence.

"Everything okay?" Priya asked, looking between them.

"Fine," Margaret said. "We were just chatting."

Carolyn stood up abruptly. "I have to go. I'm sorry. I can'tâ€”I have to go."

She grabbed her bag and pushed past Douglas, nearly running toward the exit. The door swung shut behind her, leaving a stunned silence in her wake.

"What was that about?" Douglas asked.

Margaret shook her head. "She's having a difficult time."

The others filtered in over the next few minutes, and workshop proceeded as plannedâ€”Nathan's new short story, a haunting piece about a man who discovers his childhood memories have been artificially implanted. The irony wasn't lost on Margaret.

They didn't talk about Carolyn. Nobody asked where she was. It was as if she'd already become a ghost, a cautionary tale they weren't yet ready to tell.

---

A week later, an email appeared in Margaret's inbox.

*Dear Margaret,*

*I've decided to take a break from the writing group. I don't think I'm ready for it right now. Maybe I never was.*

*I've been thinking about what you saidâ€”about the difference between having written something and being someone who writes. You're right. I wanted the result without the process. I wanted to skip to the end.*

*The thing is, I didn't even realize what I was doing until it was too late. It started so small. Just a little help here, a polished paragraph there. And then suddenly I couldn't remember what my own voice sounded like anymore. The AI was always better. Faster. More correct. Why struggle when the machine could give me what I wanted immediately?*

*But you asked me something I haven't been able to stop thinking about: what do I actually want? And I realized the honest answer is that I don't know anymore. I wanted to be a writer because I thought it would make me feel special, accomplished, meaningful. I never really thought about whether I wanted to writeâ€”the actual act of it, the hours of frustration and failure. I just wanted to have written.*

*Maybe that's why the AI was so seductive. It offered me the identity without the work. The prestige without the pain.*

*I'm not sure where I go from here. Maybe I try again, for real this time. Maybe I find something else to pour myself into. But I wanted to thank youâ€”for asking hard questions, and for not letting me off easy. The kindest thing anyone can do is tell the truth, even when it hurts.*

*I'm sorry for wasting the group's time with work that wasn't mine. I hope you can forgive me.*

*â€” Carolyn*

Margaret read the email three times. Then she forwarded it to the rest of the group without comment.

The responses came quickly. Douglas expressed relief that they finally had clarity. Priya felt sad. Nathan was vindicated but uncomfortable about feeling vindicated. Elise wanted to reach out to Carolyn, offer support. Omar thought they should discuss whether to invite her back eventually, if she truly wanted to learn.

Margaret didn't respond to any of them. She was thinking about something Carolyn had written: *I couldn't remember what my own voice sounded like anymore.*

That, she thought, was the real danger. Not the cheating, not the fraud, but the erasure. The slow replacement of self with something smoother, more efficient, less alive. The seduction of competence without struggle, of product without process.

She'd seen it happening elsewhere, too. In student papers that read like well-crafted nothing. In articles that covered all the points without actually saying anything. In the creeping sameness of so much online writing, as if the whole internet were being gently sanded into one vast, featureless surface.

The Wednesday Circle had survived, but something had been lost. Not just Carolyn's membership, but a kind of innocenceâ€”the assumption that everyone at the table was engaged in the same struggle, playing by the same rules. Now they would always wonder. Now they would look at each other's pages and feel that flicker of doubt.

Was that sentence too clean? Was that metaphor too perfect? Was this person really here, really present in the work, or had they handed themselves over to something that could simulate presence without possessing it?

These were the questions that would haunt writers' groups from now on, Margaret realized. The questions that would haunt all creative communities, all spaces where humans came together to share the products of their minds. How do you build trust in an age of synthetic text? How do you maintain a community grounded in authenticity when authenticity itself can be counterfeited?

She didn't have answers. But she knew, at least, what she had to do next.

---

The following Wednesday, Margaret arrived early as always. She'd prepared something specialâ€”not a manuscript, but a proposal.

"Before we start tonight's workshop," she said, once everyone had settled into their chairs, "I want to suggest something new."

The others looked at her expectantly. The chair where Carolyn used to sit remained empty, a wound they hadn't yet figured out how to heal.

"I think we should change how we do things," Margaret continued. "Not the critiquesâ€”those can stay the same. But I think we should add something. A show of process. Each time someone submits work, they also share something about how they wrote it. Drafts, notes, false starts. The messy middle of creation."

"You want us to show our mess?" Elise asked.

"I want us to show our humanity. The things that AI can't fake. The crossed-out lines, the abandoned tangents, the moments of doubt and breakthrough that only happen when a real person is struggling with real language."

"That's vulnerable," Priya said slowly. "That's asking a lot."

"It is. But I think it's the only way forward. We can't un-invent the technology that's out there. We can't prevent people from using it. What we can do is create spaces where the process matters as much as the product. Where we value the struggle, not just the result."

Nathan was nodding. "I like it. I've always thought the most interesting thing about writing isn't the final draftâ€”it's watching someone discover what they're trying to say."

"It might chase some people away," Douglas warned. "People who just want validation, who aren't ready to expose their failures."

"Maybe those people need a different kind of group," Margaret said. "And maybe that's okay. We don't have to be everything to everyone. We just have to be honest about what we're trying to build."

They discussed it for an hour, refining the proposal, anticipating objections, working out logistics. By the time they finished, something had shifted in the roomâ€”a new sense of purpose, a collective recommitment to the messy, inefficient, gloriously human business of putting words on a page.

Workshop that night was different. When Nathan shared his story, he also shared the six failed openings he'd written before finding the right one. When Elise offered her critique, she talked about how Nathan's struggles mirrored her own, how seeing his process helped her understand her reader response. The conversation was deeper, more connected, more alive.

Walking home afterward, Margaret thought about Carolyn again. She wondered if the younger woman would ever find her way back to writingâ€”real writing, the difficult kind. She hoped so. The world needed more people willing to fail in pursuit of their vision, not fewer.

The technology wasn't going away. The temptation would always be there, whispering that there was an easier path, a shortcut to competence. But maybe, in small rooms, at scarred wooden tables, over cups of cooling coffee, people could still come together to do the hard thing. To struggle. To fail. To occasionally, miraculously, succeed.

Margaret had been writing for forty years. She'd produced two novels, countless essays, a lifetime of words that mattered to her even if they'd never made her famous. And she knew, with a certainty that required no proof, that every sentence had been hers. Every awkward phrase, every clunky metaphor, every hard-won moment of graceâ€”they belonged to her, because she had earned them through the alchemy of effort and time.

That was worth protecting. That was worth fighting for.

The Wednesday Circle would continue. Changed, perhaps. Warier, certainly. But still committed to the fundamental proposition that had brought them together in the first place: that human beings making art was worth something, even in an age when machines could make a passable imitation.

Especially in that age.

Because the struggle wasn't the price of writing.

The struggle was the point.

---

*THE END*
